newsitem.title: USA: New home sales at 18-year peak in 1996.
newsitem.headline: New home sales at 18-year peak in 1996.

text.p: New home sales in 1996 were the strongest in 18 years, the government said Tuesday, easing only slightly at the end of the year as a key private-sector gauge of overall economic activity signaled steady moderate growth ahead.
New home sales edged down 1 percent in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 783,000 units after a revised 17.7 percent surge in November.
But for all of 1996, sales climbed 13.3 percent from 1995 to 756,000 -- the best performance since 817,000 new homes were sold in 1978, the department said.
Analysts said strong job growth and relatively low mortgage rates accounted for the strong housing activity, though they forecast some easing in the sales pace this year.

Separately, the Conference Board in New York said its index of leading indicators gained 0.1 percent in December after a revised 0.2 percent November rise -- enough to point to ongoing expansion six to nine months ahead.
The latest reports showing a strong economic close to 1996, but a moderating tone ahead, came as Federal Reserve policy makers were preparing for a two-day meeting to plot interest-rate strategy.
Most analysts were betting the U.S. central bank would decide Wednesday to keep rates steady in the absence of a clear-cut inflationary risk amid a moderating economic tempo.
Nearly seven years after the current expansion began in March 1991, the economy still shows significant strength in key sectors like housing.

December's sales rate of 783,000 was 14.6 percent above the rate a year earlier in December 1995 of 683,000. That followed an upward revision in November sales that previously had been reported rising only 14.2 percent to a rate of 772,000.

"It basically tells us that home sales activity continues to be somwhat brisk," said economist David Lereah of the Mortgage Bankers Association, "There is still a very healthy appetite out there to buy homes."

Mortgage rates have recently begun to creep upward, though in December the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. said rates for a 30-year mortgage averaged 7.60 percent, down from 7.62 percent in November. But it was higher than the 7.20 percent mortgage rate available a year earlier, in December 1995.

One favorable sign for the industry was that inventories of finished but unsold homes were leaner in December than they had been a year ago. The Commerce Department estimated there were 5.2 months' worth of homes available at last month's sales rate, down from 6.6 months' worth in December 1995.

"There has been a very positive reduction in unsold inventory in 1996," said economist David Seiders of the National Association of Home Builders, adding "The supply-demand relationship is better going into 1997 than it was going into 1996."

Nonetheless, Seiders anticipated 1997 sales of new homes would fall back by about 8 percent to 9 percent this year to around 690,000. A slowdown would be normal after such a strong sales year as was recorded in 1996, he said.

Sales in December were cushioned by a huge 46.7 percent increase in sales in the Midwest to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 176,000, the strongest sales pace since December 1993, when new homes were selling in the region at a rate of 206,000 a year.
In all other regions, sales were down in December.
In the Northeast, sales fell 3.3 percent to a rate of 87,000 a year and in the South they decreased 6.7 percent to 335,000. Sales in the West were down 16.7 percent to 185,000 a year.

Sales of new homes peaked in 1996 at a rate of 820,000 a year in August and have declined in three of the four months since then for which figures have been released. Sales were down 5 percent in September and fell 13.7 percent in October before surging in November and then dropping again in December.
The Conference Board's leading index showed increases in six of its 10 components in December, led by a bigger money supply and a longer factory workweek.
The leading negative components were higher weekly claims for state unemployment insurance and lower factory orders for consumer goods.
